The first Board of Trustees must
have been fully aware of the great
prestige that would some day accrue to Hopkins because they made
certain that their signatures could
not be missed. They signed the document in one place and then had
their name and seal in another. In

In a column appearing in the
St. John's Collegian, with contents
along the same line as that which
made up our own "Theater Views"
of times gone by, the Mr. Langfeld
of St. John's recently burst out into
the following spirited critique: "A
triple pooie-pooie to this tune,
'You're My Thrill,' as played by
anybody. The tune stinks--the
Ithelody is terrible, and the words
even worse. Reminds one of its
somewhat similar recordure,
Other Words, We're Through.
Both tunes are lousy—and that is
-pretty tough to take—what with two
putrid ditties on the same platter.'

J. H. U. Students' Tuition Fees Now
Three Times As Much As In 1913
terious gloom which surrounds on
every side the area of ascertained
truth.
"Hence universities are places of
research, of diligent inquiry for new
or forgotten truth.- This function
is quite as indispensable as either of
the two former. It is indispensable
for two reasons: First, because a
university which is not a place of
research will not long continue to
be a good place of teaching; and
secondly, because this incessant,
quiet, single-minded search after
new truth is the condition of both
material and intellectual progress
for the nation and for the race."
Yet Eliot had not always felt this.
At the time of his inauguration in
1869, he had spoken of the "prime
'business" of professors as "regular
assiduous class teaching." It was
only after witnessing the great success of the research principle at the
Johns Hopkins University that he
made his about-face'.

Is the cost of a college year increasing? With the recent announce'

so. And yet when the reports frolD

College tuitions—and these ill'

Clearly outplaying the Navy
stickmen, Mt. Washington, led by
Fred Stieber and Lorne Guild, severely trounced the Middies at the
latier's field last Saturday. The
Wolfpack pulled ahead to win by
11-4 after battling through the first
quarter on even terms with the Sail01-s.
Mt. Washington's uprising came
in the second period after a gallant
stand by the Navy had held the
score at 2-2. Converting four goals
in rapid succession, the, Wolfpack
quickly drew a commanding lead
of 6-2 and left no doubt as to their
superiority over the Middies. Substitutes were then inserted by the
Mt. Washington coaches, and every
one of their many reserves saw action before the end of the game.
Guild and Stieber led in the scoring, both tallying 4 goals to account
for 8 of the 11 points.

Calls For Following of Labor

Economic Kindergarten

Professors Speak
Drs. Mitchell and Blumberg
Talk At Evening Session
In Levering
A plea for the middle class to
follow the leadership of the radical labor movement in bringing on
an economic revolution was made
by A. J. Muste at last Saturday afternon's session of the Baltimore
Kindergarten for Economic Literacy, held in Levering Hall.
At the evening session, a symposium was held on the subject
Prohibiting Poverty, a book written
by Prestonia Mann Martin. The
conservative standpoint was presented by Jdhn L. Alcock, past
president of the Association of
Commerce; the Socialist attitude
was,given by Dr. Broadus Mitchell,
associate . professor of political
economy at the Hopkins; the Communist stand was presented by Dr.
Albert E. Blumberg, instructor of
philosophy at this University.
Mr. Muste, organizer of the
American Workers' Party, was
born in Holland, and came to America as a child. He at first took up
ministerial work, holding pastoral
posts in New York and Boston, but
in recent years has turned to active
work in the labor movement. He is
the former chairman of the faculty of Brookwood Labor College,
Natonah, N. Y.
Throwing aside the idea of gradually building a Socialistic system
within a capitalistic system as not
feasible, Mr. Muste proposed three
immediate measures in bringing
about a socialized economic order.
These measures were a $10,000,000,000 public works program; a
guaranteed minimum wage of $30
a week per person, employed or unployed ; and the unrestricted right
of all workers and farmers to organize. He advocated the socialization of the basic ;industries, of land,
of minerals, and .of water power.

Long regarded as one of the outstanding physical chemists in the
world, Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel
Laureate in Chemistry for 1932,
will deliver the fourth Dohme lecture on the afternoon of May 4.
Dr. Langmuir's address will be
the Ceature of the fifth annual conference of Founders of the Johns
Hopkins National Fellowship Plan
which will convene at the Hopkins
next Friday.
The Fellowship Plan, which was
started in 1929, involves the training of chemists who are fitted to
contribute to
he fundamental
chemical progress.. Fellowships are

Field Trip Starts This Morning As
Class-Room Work Ends In
Geology Department

Spring Formal Held
Election of officers of the De
Molay Club for the coming year
were held last Thursday. Morris
Goodhart was elected president;
Emmert B. Daub, vice-president,
and Edward D. Crouch, secretarytreasurer.
The third annual spring formal
was given in conjunction with the
Cotillion on Saturday, April 21,
at which time a pm was given to
;Dr. T. F. Hubbard, faculty adviser
of the organization.
The last meeting of the -De Molay
Club this year will be held in Levering Hall on May 10, beginning
with supper at 6 P.

Lectures and classroom instruction have come to an end for the
year as far as the students in geology are concerned because ot the
annual excprsion which is scheduled to last from May 1 to May 13.
The northern field trip for this
year started this morning at the
northeast corner of Charles and
University Parkway, proceeds to
Pennsylvania, where tnagnatite and
coal mines will be visited, to New
Jersey, and to New York, where
stops will be made at .Peekskill,
Glens Falls, Big Shanty, Port
Henry, Mineville, Witherbee, Au
Sable Chasm, Lyon Mountain, Geuverneur, and Clinton.

Stanley Blumberg, editor-inchief of the NEWS-LETTER, has
been requested to speak to the
journalists of Baltimore City College this week.
The occasion of his talk is a
meeting of the Press Club and the
journalism class of the scbool. He
is a former editor of the Collegian,
the City College newspaper.

The original charter of this university which has lain folded away
in the President's office among
many insignificant documents since
1867, being disturbed only upon
special occasions when it was produced, unfolded among many abs
and aaahs and then scrutinized and
read by romantic alumni, came into
its own last week when Dr. Ames
had it framed in a special ray filter
substance and put on display in his
office.

Miss Sue Hastings, one of the
foremost puppeteers in the country
along with Tony Sarg, presented
and demonstrated her marionettes
before the Elementary Education
Club at New York University on
Friday, April 13, at 11 a., m. It is
likely that even without brains the
puppets behaved themselves in more
orderly fashion than the humans
who were rioting and demonstrating during the same hour.

The first Board of Trustees must
have been fully aware of the great
prestige that would some day accrue to Hopkins because they made
certain that their signatures could
not be missed. They signed the document in one place and then had
their name and seal in another. In
order that their efforts will not be
unavailing, the trustees were, in
order of signing: Thomas Smith,
William Hopkins, Lewis Hopkins,
John Gassett, Alan Smith, John
Fonerden, George Doblin, George
Gill, Andrew Ridgely, Thomas Donaldson, James A. L. McClure, and
Charles J. M. Gwinn.

In a column appearing in the
St. John's Collegian, with contents
along the same line as that which
made up our own "Theater Views"
of times gone by, the Mr. Langfeld
of St. John's recently burst out into
the following spirited critique: "A
triple pooie-pooie to this tune,
'You're My Thrill,' as played by
anybody. The tune stinks--the
Ithelody is terrible, and the words
even worse. Reminds one of its
somewhat similar recordure,
Other Words, We're Through.
Both tunes are lousy—and that is
-pretty tough to take—what with two
putrid ditties on the same platter.'

J. H. U. Students' Tuition Fees Now
Three Times As Much As In 1913
terious gloom which surrounds on
every side the area of ascertained
truth.
"Hence universities are places of
research, of diligent inquiry for new
or forgotten truth.- This function
is quite as indispensable as either of
the two former. It is indispensable
for two reasons: First, because a
university which is not a place of
research will not long continue to
be a good place of teaching; and
secondly, because this incessant,
quiet, single-minded search after
new truth is the condition of both
material and intellectual progress
for the nation and for the race."
Yet Eliot had not always felt this.
At the time of his inauguration in
1869, he had spoken of the "prime
'business" of professors as "regular
assiduous class teaching." It was
only after witnessing the great success of the research principle at the
Johns Hopkins University that he
made his about-face'.

Cost Of A College Year Is Generally Increasing, Survey Shows
Is the cost of a college year increasing? With the recent announce'
!tient of a raise in ,the tuition at
Johns Hopkins from $400 to $450/
to the students here it would seen!
so. And yet when the reports frolD
the 1,500 colleges and universities
established throughout the United
:States are considered, the assumr
don is shown to be only partly true.
College tuitions—and these ill'
dude J. H. U.—have never covered
the cost of college instruction, and
seldom do at present, although there
is a tendency in that direction in 3
small number of institutions.
Tuition rates 20 years ago, as revealed in a survey just made by the
United States Office of Education/
were relatively low, and so standardized that for a period of fiftY
years few changes had been made'
In 1914-15 rates began to be re"
vised upward, and ten years late
many tuitions had been doubled.

in 25 colleges and universities, e%

Clearly outplaying the Navy
stickmen, Mt. Washington, led by
Fred Stieber and Lorne Guild, severely trounced the Middies at the
latier's field last Saturday. The
Wolfpack pulled ahead to win by
11-4 after battling through the first
quarter on even terms with the Sail01-s.
Mt. Washington's uprising came
in the second period after a gallant
stand by the Navy had held the
score at 2-2. Converting four goals
in rapid succession, the, Wolfpack
quickly drew a commanding lead
of 6-2 and left no doubt as to their
superiority over the Middies. Substitutes were then inserted by the
Mt. Washington coaches, and every
one of their many reserves saw action before the end of the game.
Guild and Stieber led in the scoring, both tallying 4 goals to account
for 8 of the 11 points.

Professors Speak
Drs. Mitchell and Blumberg
Talk At Evening Session
In Levering
A plea for the middle class to
follow the leadership of the radical labor movement in bringing on
an economic revolution was made
by A. J. Muste at last Saturday afternon's session of the Baltimore
Kindergarten for Economic Literacy, held in Levering Hall.
At the evening session, a symposium was held on the subject
Prohibiting Poverty, a book written
by Prestonia Mann Martin. The
conservative standpoint was presented by Jdhn L. Alcock, past
president of the Association of
Commerce; the Socialist attitude
was,given by Dr. Broadus Mitchell,
associate . professor of political
economy at the Hopkins; the Communist stand was presented by Dr.
Albert E. Blumberg, instructor of
philosophy at this University.
Mr. Muste, organizer of the
American Workers' Party, was
born in Holland, and came to America as a child. He at first took up
ministerial work, holding pastoral
posts in New York and Boston, but
in recent years has turned to active
work in the labor movement. He is
the former chairman of the faculty of Brookwood Labor College,
Natonah, N. Y.
Throwing aside the idea of gradually building a Socialistic system
within a capitalistic system as not
feasible, Mr. Muste proposed three
immediate measures in bringing
about a socialized economic order.
These measures were a $10,000,000,000 public works program; a
guaranteed minimum wage of $30
a week per person, employed or unployed ; and the unrestricted right
of all workers and farmers to organize. He advocated the socialization of the basic ;industries, of land,
of minerals, and .of water power.

Long regarded as one of the outstanding physical chemists in the
world, Dr. Irving Langmuir, Nobel
Laureate in Chemistry for 1932,
will deliver the fourth Dohme lecture on the afternoon of May 4.
Dr. Langmuir's address will be
the Ceature of the fifth annual conference of Founders of the Johns
Hopkins National Fellowship Plan
which will convene at the Hopkins
next Friday.
The Fellowship Plan, which was
started in 1929, involves the training of chemists who are fitted to
contribute to
he fundamental
chemical progress.. Fellowships are
p:-ovided by leading individuals and
con mrations throughout the country.

Field Trip Starts This Morning As
Class-Room Work Ends In
Geology Department

Spring Formal Held
Election of officers of the De
Molay Club for the coming year
were held last Thursday. Morris
Goodhart was elected president;
Emmert B. Daub, vice-president,
and Edward D. Crouch, secretarytreasurer.
The third annual spring formal
was given in conjunction with the
Cotillion on Saturday, April 21,
at which time a pm was given to
;Dr. T. F. Hubbard, faculty adviser
of the organization.
The last meeting of the -De Molay
Club this year will be held in Levering Hall on May 10, beginning
with supper at 6 P.

Lectures and classroom instruction have come to an end for the
year as far as the students in geology are concerned because ot the
annual excprsion which is scheduled to last from May 1 to May 13.
The northern field trip for this
year started this morning at the
northeast corner of Charles and
University Parkway, proceeds to
Pennsylvania, where tnagnatite and
coal mines will be visited, to New
Jersey, and to New York, where
stops will be made at .Peekskill,
Glens Falls, Big Shanty, Port
Henry, Mineville, Witherbee, Au
Sable Chasm, Lyon Mountain, Geuverneur, and Clinton.

Stanley Blumberg, editor-inchief of the NEWS-LETTER, has
been requested to speak to the
journalists of Baltimore City College this week.
The occasion of his talk is a
meeting of the Press Club and the
journalism class of the scbool. He
is a former editor of the Collegian,
the City College newspaper.

edition is expected to come out this
week. The edition is edited by Edwin Greenlaw, Charles Grosvenor
